canonical_explanation.text: Integration is the inverse process of differentiation. If d/dx[F(x)]=f(x), then ∫f(x)dx=F(x)+C. Methods include substitution (change of variable), partial fractions (for rational functions), and integration by parts (∫udv=uv-∫vdu). The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus states that ∫ₐᵇf(x)dx = F(b)-F(a) where F'(x)=f(x). Key properties of definite integrals help simplify evaluation.
rules: Integration by parts: ∫u·v dx = u∫v dx - ∫(u'·∫v dx)dx (ILATE rule for choosing u)

questions.explanation_correct: Using the power rule: ∫xⁿdx = xⁿ⁺¹/(n+1) + C. Here n=4, so ∫x⁴dx = x⁵/5 + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apply ∫xⁿdx = xⁿ⁺¹/(n+1) + C. With n=4: x⁴⁺¹/(4+1) = x⁵/5 + C.

questions.explanation_correct: Since d/dx(sin x) = cos x, the anti-derivative of cos x is sin x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The derivative of sin x is cos x, so ∫cos x dx = sin x + C.

questions.explanation_correct: The exponential function eˣ is its own derivative, so ∫eˣdx = eˣ + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since d/dx(eˣ) = eˣ, the anti-derivative of eˣ is simply eˣ + C.

questions.explanation_correct: ∫(1/x)dx = log|x| + C. This is a standard integral; the power rule does not apply when n = −1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When n = −1, ∫x⁻¹dx cannot use the power rule. Instead, ∫(1/x)dx = log|x| + C.

questions.explanation_correct: Since d/dx(tan x) = sec²x, we have ∫sec²x dx = tan x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The derivative of tan x is sec²x, so the anti-derivative of sec²x is tan x + C.

questions.explanation_correct: True. Since d/dx(−cos x) = sin x, the anti-derivative of sin x is −cos x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: d/dx(−cos x) = −(−sin x) = sin x. So ∫sin x dx = −cos x + C is correct.

questions.explanation_correct: ∫3x²dx = 3·x³/3 = x³ and ∫2x dx = 2·x²/2 = x². So the answer is x³ + x² + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Integrate term by term: ∫3x²dx = x³, ∫2x dx = x². Result: x³ + x² + C. Note option C simplifies to the same as B.

questions.explanation_correct: 1/√x = x⁻¹/². Using the power rule: ∫x⁻¹/²dx = x¹/²/(1/2) + C = 2√x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Write 1/√x = x⁻¹/². Then ∫x⁻¹/²dx = x^(1/2)/(1/2) + C = 2√x + C.

questions.explanation_correct: ∫sin x dx = −cos x and ∫cos x dx = sin x. So ∫(sin x + cos x)dx = −cos x + sin x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Integrate term by term: ∫sin x dx = −cos x and ∫cos x dx = sin x. Answer: −cos x + sin x + C.

questions.explanation_correct: Since d/dx(aˣ/log a) = aˣ·log a/log a = aˣ, we have ∫aˣdx = aˣ/log a + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The standard integral ∫aˣdx = aˣ/(log a) + C for a > 0, a ≠ 1.
Substitute u = 2x+3, du = 2dx. Then ∫u⁵(du/2) = (1/2)·u⁶/6 = (2x+3)⁶/12 + C.

questions.explanation_correct: Let u = 3x, du = 3dx. ∫sin u·(du/3) = −cos u/3 + C = −cos(3x)/3 + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Substituting u = 3x: ∫sin(3x)dx = (1/3)(−cos(3x)) + C = −cos(3x)/3 + C.

questions.explanation_correct: Let u = x², du = 2x dx. Then ∫eᵘ du = eᵘ + C = eˣ² + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Substitute u = x², so du = 2x dx. The integral becomes ∫eᵘdu = eᵘ + C = eˣ² + C.

options.text: sin x · log(1 + sin x) + C

questions.explanation_correct: Let u = 1 + sin x, du = cos x dx. ∫du/u = log|u| + C = log|1 + sin x| + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Substitute u = 1 + sin x, du = cos x dx. Then ∫du/u = log|u| + C = log|1 + sin x| + C.

questions.explanation_correct: ∫tan x dx = ∫sin x/cos x dx. Let u = cos x, du = −sin x dx. ∫−du/u = −log|cos x| + C = log|sec x| + C. Both A and B are equivalent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Write tan x = sin x/cos x. Substituting u = cos x: −∫du/u = −log|cos x| = log|sec x|. Options A and B are the same.

questions.explanation_correct: Let u = x² + 1, du = 2x dx. ∫(du/2)/u = (1/2)log|u| + C = (1/2)log(x² + 1) + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Substitute u = x²+1, du = 2x dx. Then ∫x dx/(x²+1) = (1/2)∫du/u = (1/2)log(x²+1) + C.
Decompose: 1/(x²−1) = (1/2)[1/(x−1) − 1/(x+1)]. Integrate each term to get (1/2)log|(x−1)/(x+1)| + C.

questions.explanation_correct: This is a standard integral: ∫dx/(x²+1) = tan⁻¹x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ∫dx/(x²+1) = tan⁻¹x + C is a standard result (since d/dx(tan⁻¹x) = 1/(1+x²)).

questions.explanation_correct: By parts: u = x, dv = eˣdx. Then du = dx, v = eˣ. ∫x·eˣdx = xeˣ − ∫eˣdx = xeˣ − eˣ + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Integration by parts with u = x (ILATE: algebraic first), dv = eˣdx gives xeˣ − ∫eˣdx = xeˣ − eˣ + C.

questions.explanation_correct: By parts: u = log x, dv = dx. du = (1/x)dx, v = x. ∫log x dx = x log x − ∫x·(1/x)dx = x log x − x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Use integration by parts: u = log x, dv = dx. Then ∫log x dx = x log x − ∫1 dx = x log x − x + C.

questions.question_text: In the ILATE rule for integration by parts, 'I' stands for Inverse trigonometric functions and they should be chosen as the first function (u).
questions.explanation_correct: True. ILATE stands for Inverse trig, Logarithmic, Algebraic, Trigonometric, Exponential. Functions appearing earlier in this list are preferred as u (the first function).
questions.explanation_incorrect: ILATE is the priority order: Inverse trig > Logarithmic > Algebraic > Trigonometric > Exponential for choosing u.

questions.explanation_correct: Complete the square: x²+4x+13 = (x+2)²+9 = (x+2)²+3². Using ∫dx/(u²+a²) = (1/a)tan⁻¹(u/a), we get (1/3)tan⁻¹((x+2)/3) + C.
Using the standard form ∫dx/√(a²−x²) = sin⁻¹(x/a) + C with a = 3: sin⁻¹(x/3) + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is of the form ∫dx/√(a²−x²) = sin⁻¹(x/a) + C. Here a = 3, giving sin⁻¹(x/3) + C.

questions.explanation_correct: By parts twice: u=x², dv=eˣdx → x²eˣ − 2∫xeˣdx. Then ∫xeˣdx = xeˣ−eˣ. So x²eˣ − 2(xeˣ−eˣ) + C = eˣ(x²−2x+2) + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apply by parts twice. First: x²eˣ − 2∫xeˣdx. Second: ∫xeˣdx = xeˣ − eˣ. Combining: eˣ(x²−2x+2) + C.
Decompose: A/(x+1)+B/(x+2). Solving gives A=1, B=1. Integrating: log|x+1| + log|x+2| + C.

questions.explanation_correct: Rewrite: eˣ(sec x + sec x·tan x). This is of the form ∫eˣ[f(x)+f'(x)]dx = eˣf(x)+C where f(x) = sec x and f'(x) = sec x·tan x. So the answer is eˣ·sec x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Note eˣ(sec x + sec x tan x) matches ∫eˣ[f(x)+f'(x)]dx = eˣf(x)+C with f(x)=sec x. Answer: eˣ sec x + C.

questions.explanation_correct: Complete the square: x²+2x+5 = (x+1)²+4. Using ∫dx/√(u²+a²) = log|u+√(u²+a²)| + C with u=x+1, a=2: log|(x+1)+√(x²+2x+5)| + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Write x²+2x+5 = (x+1)²+2². Apply ∫dx/√(u²+a²) = log|u+√(u²+a²)|+C to get log|(x+1)+√(x²+2x+5)|+C.

questions.explanation_correct: Since d/dx(−cot x) = cosec²x, we have ∫cosec²x dx = −cot x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The derivative of −cot x is cosec²x, so the anti-derivative of cosec²x is −cot x + C.

options.text: x cos x − sin x + C
x sin x + cos x + C

questions.explanation_correct: By parts: u = x, dv = sin x dx. du = dx, v = −cos x. ∫x sin x dx = −x cos x − ∫(−cos x)dx = −x cos x + sin x + C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Integration by parts: u=x, dv=sin x dx → v=−cos x. Result: −x cos x + ∫cos x dx = −x cos x + sin x + C.

questions.question_text: ∫(x² + 1)/(x⁴ + 1) dx can be simplified by dividing numerator and denominator by x². Which substitution then works?
questions.explanation_correct: Dividing by x²: (1+1/x²)/(x²+1/x²). Note x²+1/x² = (x−1/x)²+2. Let t = x−1/x, dt = (1+1/x²)dx. The integral becomes ∫dt/(t²+2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: After dividing by x², the integrand becomes (1+1/x²)/((x−1/x)²+2). Setting t = x−1/x gives dt = (1+1/x²)dx, simplifying the integral.
Anti-derivative of x² is x³/3. Evaluate: (1)³/3 − (0)³/3 = 1/3.
Evaluate: [−cos x] from 0 to π/2 = −cos(π/2) + cos(0) = 0 + 1 = 1.

questions.explanation_correct: ∫₁ᵉ (1/x)dx = [log|x|]₁ᵉ = log e − log 1 = 1 − 0 = 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anti-derivative is log|x|. Evaluate: log(e) − log(1) = 1 − 0 = 1.

questions.question_text: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus states that if F is an anti-derivative of a continuous function f on [a, b], then ∫ₐᵇf(x)dx = F(b) − F(a).
questions.explanation_correct: True. This is the second part of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, which connects anti-differentiation with definite integration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is the correct statement of the Fundamental Theorem (second part). It provides the practical method for evaluating definite integrals.

questions.explanation_correct: ∫₀¹ eˣdx = [eˣ]₀¹ = e¹ − e⁰ = e − 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaluate: [eˣ] from 0 to 1 = e − 1.
Use cos²x = (1+cos2x)/2. Then ∫₀^(π/2) (1+cos2x)/2 dx = (1/2)(π/2 + 0) = π/4.
Anti-derivative: x²+x. Evaluate at limits: (2²+2) − (0+0) = 6.

questions.explanation_correct: sin³x = sin x(1−cos²x). Let u=cos x, du=−sin x dx. When x=0, u=1; x=π/2, u=0. ∫₁⁰ −(1−u²)du = ∫₀¹(1−u²)du = [u−u³/3]₀¹ = 1−1/3 = 2/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Write sin³x = sin x·sin²x = sin x(1−cos²x). Substituting u=cos x transforms it to ∫₀¹(1−u²)du = 2/3.

questions.explanation_correct: ∫₀^π sin x dx = [−cos x]₀^π = −cos π − (−cos 0) = −(−1) + 1 = 1 + 1 = 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaluate: [−cos x] from 0 to π = −cos π + cos 0 = 1 + 1 = 2.

questions.question_text: ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx = −∫ᵇₐ f(x) dx. This property means:

options.text: Swapping limits changes the sign of the integral
f(x) must be an odd function
The integral depends only on the integrand, not the limits

questions.explanation_correct: This property states that reversing the limits of integration changes the sign of the definite integral.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When we interchange the upper and lower limits, the definite integral changes sign: ∫ₐᵇ = −∫ᵇₐ.

questions.explanation_correct: For an odd function f(−x) = −f(x), the integral over a symmetric interval [−a, a] is zero because the positive and negative contributions cancel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If f(−x) = −f(x) (odd function), then ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 0. For even functions, ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 2∫₀ᵃ f(x)dx.

questions.explanation_correct: x³ is an odd function (f(−x) = −x³ = −f(x)). For odd functions, ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since x³ is odd, ∫₋₁¹ x³dx = 0. Alternatively: [x⁴/4]₋₁¹ = 1/4 − 1/4 = 0.

questions.question_text: Using the property ∫₀ᵃ f(x)dx = ∫₀ᵃ f(a−x)dx, evaluate ∫₀^(π/2) sin x/(sin x + cos x) dx:
questions.explanation_correct: Let I = ∫₀^(π/2) sin x/(sin x+cos x)dx. Using f(a−x): I = ∫₀^(π/2) cos x/(cos x+sin x)dx. Adding: 2I = ∫₀^(π/2) 1 dx = π/2. So I = π/4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apply the property: I also equals ∫₀^(π/2) cos x/(cos x+sin x)dx. Adding both: 2I = ∫₀^(π/2)1 dx = π/2, so I = π/4.

questions.explanation_correct: x⁴ is an even function. ∫₋₂² x⁴dx = 2∫₀² x⁴dx = 2[x⁵/5]₀² = 2(32/5) = 64/5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since x⁴ is even: ∫₋₂² x⁴dx = 2∫₀² x⁴dx = 2·(2⁵/5) = 2·(32/5) = 64/5.

questions.explanation_correct: Using ∫₀ᵃf(x)dx = ∫₀ᵃf(a−x)dx: I = ∫₀^π(π−x)sin x dx = π∫₀^π sin x dx − I. So 2I = π[−cos x]₀^π = π(1+1) = 2π. I = π.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apply the property: I = ∫₀^π(π−x)sin(π−x)dx = ∫₀^π(π−x)sin x dx. Adding: 2I = π∫₀^π sin x dx = 2π, so I = π.

questions.explanation_correct: sin x ≥ 0 on [0,π] and sin x ≤ 0 on [π,2π]. So ∫₀^(2π)|sin x|dx = ∫₀^π sin x dx + ∫^(2π)_π (−sin x)dx = 2 + 2 = 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Split at π: ∫₀^π sin x dx = [−cos x]₀^π = 2. ∫_π^(2π)(−sin x)dx = [cos x]_π^(2π) = 1−(−1) = 2. Total = 4.

questions.explanation_correct: True. This is a standard property: ∫₀^(2a) f(x)dx = ∫₀ᵃ f(x)dx + ∫₀ᵃ f(2a−x)dx. If f(2a−x) = −f(x), the two integrals cancel and the sum is 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is correct. When f(2a−x) = −f(x), we get ∫₀^(2a) f(x)dx = ∫₀ᵃ[f(x)+f(2a−x)]dx = ∫₀ᵃ 0 dx = 0.

questions.explanation_correct: Let I = ∫₀^(π/2) log(tan x)dx. Using f(a−x): I = ∫₀^(π/2) log(tan(π/2−x))dx = ∫₀^(π/2) log(cot x)dx = −∫₀^(π/2) log(tan x)dx = −I. So 2I = 0, I = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apply the property with a = π/2: I = ∫₀^(π/2) log(cot x)dx = −I. Adding: 2I = 0, so I = 0.

questions.explanation_correct: Let I = ∫₀^(π/2) sin²x dx. By the property ∫₀ᵃf(x)dx = ∫₀ᵃf(a−x)dx, I also equals ∫₀^(π/2) cos²x dx. So 2I = ∫₀^(π/2)(sin²x+cos²x)dx = ∫₀^(π/2)1 dx = π/2. Hence I = π/4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the property, both integrals are equal. Their sum = ∫₀^(π/2)1 dx = π/2, so each equals π/4.

questions.explanation_correct: Using ∫₀ᵃf(x)dx = ∫₀ᵃf(a−x)dx: I = ∫₀^π(π−x)sin²x dx = π∫₀^π sin²x dx − I. So 2I = π∫₀^π sin²x dx. Now ∫₀^π sin²x dx = π/2 (using sin²x = (1−cos2x)/2). Hence 2I = π·π/2 = π²/2, giving I = π²/4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apply the property: 2I = π∫₀^π sin²x dx = π·(π/2) = π²/2. So I = π²/4.
